TextView.android:text: Dependent Events
In this lesson, we will learn how to find the probability of dependent events.
Introduction to lesson
This means, to find the probability of two events A and B that are dependent, multiply the probability of event A by the probability of event B given that A has happened.
Illustrative Examples

(a) a red marble then a blue marble?
(b) a blue marble then another blue marble?
(c) both marbles are yellow?
(d) two red marbles and a blue marble?
(e) a red marble, followed by a blue marble, then a yellow marble?
Show Solution

There are a total of 15 marbles, of which 6 are red, 5 are blue, and 4 are yellow. Note that in the problem, the marbles are drawn without replacement. Once a marble is selected, the total number of marbles decreases.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a red.
There are 6 red marbles out of 15.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing a blue.
There are 5 blue marbles. A total of 14 marbles left since the first marble was drawn and not replaced.
The probability of drawing a red marble then a blue marble is 1/7.
(b) Let A be the event of drawing a blue marble\nLet B be the event of drawing another blue marble
There are a total of 15 marbles, of which 6 are red, 5 are blue, and 4 are yellow.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a blue.
There are 5 blue marbles out of 15.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing another blue.
A blue marble is drawn and not replaced. There are now 4 blue marbles. A total of 14 marbles left.
The probability of drawing a blue marble then another blue marble is 2/21.
(c) Let A be the event of drawing a yellow marble\nLet B be the event of drawing another yellow marble
There are a total of 15 marbles, of which 6 are red, 5 are blue, and 4 are yellow.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a yellow.
There are 4 yellow marbles out of 15.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing another yellow.
A yellow marble is drawn and not replaced. There are now 3 yellow marbles. A total of 14 marbles left.
The probability of drawing a yellow marble then another yellow marble is 2/35.
(d) Let A be the event of drawing a red marble\nLet B be the event of drawing another red marble\nLet C be the event of drawing a blue marble
There are a total of 15 marbles, of which 6 are red, 5 are blue, and 4 are yellow.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a red.
There are 6 red marbles out of 15.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing another red.
A red marble is drawn and not replaced. There are now 5 red marbles. A total of 14 marbles left.
Third draw:
Probability of drawing a blue.
There are 5 blue marbles. There are a total of 13 marbles left since the second marble was drawn and not replaced.
The probability of drawing two red marbles and a blue marble is 5/91.
(e) Let A be the event of drawing a red marble\nLet B be the event of drawing a blue marble\nLet C be the event of drawing a yellow marble
There are a total of 15 marbles, of which 6 are red, 5 are blue, and 4 are yellow.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a red.
There are 6 red marbles out of 15.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing a blue.
There are 5 blue marbles. There are a total of 14 marbles left since the first marble was drawn and not replaced.
Third draw:
Probability of drawing a yellow.
There are 4 yellow marbles. There are a total of 13 marbles left since the second marble was drawn and not replaced.
The probability of drawing a red marble, followed by a blue marble, then a yellow marble is 4/91.

(a) a jack on the first draw and a king on the second draw?
(b) an ace on the first draw and another ace on the second draw?
(c) a diamond on the first draw and a black card on the second draw?
(d) a diamond on the first draw and a red card on the second draw?
Show Solution
There are a total of 52 cards, of which 4 are jack, and 4 are king.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a jack.
There are 4 jacks out of 52 cards in a deck.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing a king.
There are 4 king cards. There are a total of 51 cards left since the first card was drawn and not replaced.
The probability of drawing a jack then a king in a deck of cards is 4/663.
(b) Let A be the event of drawing an ace\nLet B be the event of drawing another ace
There are a total of 52 cards, of which 4 are ace.
First draw:
Probability of drawing an ace.
There are 4 aces out of 52 cards in a deck.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing another ace.
An ace card is drawn and not replaced. There are now 3 aces. A total of 51 cards left.
The probability of drawing an ace then another ace in a deck of cards is 3/663.
(c) Let A be the event of drawing a diamond\nLet B be the event of drawing a black card
There are a total of 52 cards, of which 13 are diamonds and 26 are black.
First draw:
Probability of drawing an ace.
There are 4 aces out of 52 cards in a deck.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing another ace.
An ace card is drawn and not replaced. There are now 3 aces. A total of 51 cards left.
The probability of drawing an ace then a black card in a deck of cards is 13/102.
(d) Let A be the event of drawing a diamond\nLet B be the event of drawing a red card
There are a total of 52 cards, of which 13 are diamonds and 26 are red.
First draw:
Probability of drawing a diamond.
There are 13 diamonds out of 52 cards in a deck.
Second draw:
Probability of drawing a red.
There are 25 red cards left since a diamond is red and was drawn without replacement. There are a total of 51 cards left.
The probability of drawing a diamond then a red card in a deck of cards is 25/104.

Let A be the event of taking out a white towel\nLet B be the event of taking out another white towel
First draw out:
Probability of taking out a white towel.
There are 4 white towels out of 10 towels.
Second draw out:
Probability of taking out another white towel.
A white towel is taken out and not returned. There are now 3 white towels. There are a total of 9 towels left.
The probability of taking out both white towels is 1/3.
Show Solution
Let A be the event of drinking a buko juice\nLet B be the event of drinking another buko juice
First drink:
Probability of drinking a buko juice.
There are 4 glasses of buko juice out of 10 juices.
Second drink:
Probability of drinking another buko juice.
One glass of buko juice was drank. There are now 3 glasses of buko juice. There are a total of 9 juices left.
The probability of drinking the two glasses of buko juice is 2/15.
Show Solution
Let A be the event of choosing a boy\nLet B be the event of choosing a girl
First to choose:
Probability of choosing a boy.
There are 18 boys out of 30 students in class
Second to choose:
Probability of choosing a girl.
There are 12 girls. There are a total of 29 students left since one boy was already chosen to present in class.
The probability of choosing a boy first and a girl on the second to present in class is 36/145.
